intro: Moehringia intricata var. tejedensis, commonly known as the Sierra Nevada bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its delicate, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale blue. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils in mountainous regions, preferring cool and moist conditions. Its leaves are often hairy and arranged in a basal rosette, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This species is part of the Campanulaceae family, which includes many other bellflowers with similar floral structures.
